utterances: When I put out a tweet and I put Reince's name in a tweet, they're all making the assumption that it's him because journalists know who the leakers are.
So if Reince wants to explain that he's not a leaker, let him do that.
That would have been big in and of itself, but Scaramucci wasn't done.
It was then revealed he called a New Yorker reporter, tore into Priebus and Bannon in what was really a not-safe-for-work tirade.
(Laughter).
And after the firestorm that created, Scaramucci later tweeted that he would refrain from using such, quote, ""colorful language going forward.
OK, so then on Friday, Reince Priebus steps down as chief of staff, and everyone thinks, looks like Scaramucci won.
Right.
There didn't seem to be any repercussions for the communications director.
What changed between Friday and Monday?
Well, John Kelly, the general, was named Priebus' replacement Friday night as well and apparently took the weekend to think about how he wanted things structure.
And it looks like the Mucc (ph) was not part of that plan.
And so today on a day when Real Donald Trump tweeted, no White House chaos...
Right, of course.
...We (laughter) have this turnover.
What does it tell us about how Kelly might act as chief of staff?
Well, Trump does like to give people at least a first round of being able to control their staff.
And Kelly's a general.
He likes hierarchy.
He likes order.
So it wouldn't be necessarily surprising that he'd want to exert some control over what had been really a chaotic scene over the last several months in the White House.
Remember; Scaramucci said in his first outing in the White House briefing room that he reported directly to the president and not to Reince Priebus.
That looked like it was in conflict with what Kelly wanted and the traditional role as a gatekeeper for the White House chief of staff.
I feel like every two weeks there's this question of, whoa, is this the moment President Trump will begin acting, quote, unquote, ""presidential""?
Is there any hope of Chief of Staff Kelly imposing the kind of order on the White House that has been so elusive up until now?
Well, that's the goal for Kelly.
He - what he did today certainly looks like him trying to exert authority and power, which is something that when somebody is in a chaotic situation, they want to show that they are really in charge.
He was able to take out one of the big players in the White House.
You know, the thing is whether or not this will last because we know that Trump likes chaos.
He's sort of like the middle of a bike wheel.
You know, everybody else is sort of the spokes that feed out of that.
A White House chief of staff is supposed to be something of a gatekeeper where everything goes through them.
That's at odds with Trump's instincts.
We'll see if that changes under Kelly.
And now the parlor game begins of who will be the new communications director.
Right.
There is that.
NPR's political editor Domenico Montanaro, thanks a lot.
You're welcome.
And tune into MORNING EDITION tomorrow morning for more on this story.
SCIENCE FRIDAY.
I'm Ira Flatow.
A brief program note.
Coming up on Monday's TALK OF THE NATION, guest host Lynn Neary will take a look at art controversies in America.
And join Neal Conan on Tuesday for a special TALK OF THE NATION broadcast from Fort Dix, New Jersey.
He'll talk about the strain of the Iraq and Afghan wars on the military and the future of the National Guard and Reserves.
But up next, this hour, winter.
It's a great time of the year to check out the night sky because, you know, the cold, crisp air is very clear.
There's a lot to see.
You can see a lot more.
And you may not see the Star of Bethlehem, but you might catch just a glimpse of your favorite winter constellation.
And in March there's going to be a total eclipse of the moon.
And you don't have to wait that long to see something because this Sunday, early Sunday morning, a rare planetary trio is scheduled to make an appearance.
So for the rest of the hour we're going to get a winter stargazing guide from our favorite meteorologist by day, amateur astronomer by night.
And he'll help answer one of the questions we get most of the time, most often about gift giving this time of the year, and that is, how do you buy a telescope?
You know, there's a lot of hype in the magazines.
What should do if you want to buy a telescope?
What do I need to know?
So if you'd like to join our discussion, our number is 1-800-989-8255, 1-800-989-TALK.
Joe Rao is the SPACE.com night sky columnist, the sky watch contributor to the New York Times and associate and guest lecturer at the Hayden Planetarium at the Rose Center for Earth and Space.
He's also a meteorologist at Cablevision News 12 Network of Greater New York in Westchester.
He joins us today from his office there.
Welcome back to the program, Joe.
How you doing, Ira?
It's nice to be chatting with you again.
Yeah.
It's always good to hear from you.
Give us an idea of the sky showing up as we speak.
I mentioned a planet trio in the same part of the sky?
Tell us about that.
Yeah.
This is going to be very interesting.
There are three planets right now that are visible in the early morning sky, just before sun up, over in the East/Southeast.
They are Mercury, the planet Jupiter, and the planet Mars.

And these three planets are going to be - already they're fairly close together, but on Sunday morning they're going to cluster to within about a degree of each other in the sky, making kind of like a tiny arrowhead, if you will, with Mars at the arrow point.

And if you want to get an idea of just how tight this is, one degree, keep in mind that the moon, the full moon, or the sun - but you don't want to look at the sun, but basically the same size - the moon is about a half degree in diameter.
So we're talking about three planets clustered into a very tight little spot in the sky into an area that's roughly about twice the moon's width.
And again, they'll be low down in the East-Southeastern sky.
Oh, the best time to look probably be about a half to - a half hour to three-quarters of an hour before the sun comes up, any time over the next few mornings.
But the morning when they'll be closest together will be early on Sunday morning.
So if you're heading back from that late night holiday shoppingâ€¦
Well, the only drawback about this cluster, it would be more spectacular if we had three - or if all three planets were close to equal brightness.
But Jupiter will shine the brightest.
Mercury won't be quite as bright, but that should also be quite evident.
The only problem planet is Mars.
Mars right now at this point in time is on the other side of the sun, or the other side of the solar system from us.
It's rather dim.
It might not be visible with the unaided eye.
You may need a pair of binoculars to pick it out, along with the two other planets - far, far from the earth now.
Interestingly, Mars is beginning to make the turnaround, so to speak.
As I said, it's on the opposite side of the sun from us.
Next year at this time, one year from now, Mars will be near what we call opposition, and it will shine brilliantly.
But it's going to be a long, slow climb up between now and then for it to get bright.
And again, right now it's kind of dim and you'll probably need Mercury and Jupiter to help find it early in the morning hours.
But it's still kind of interesting that three planets are all, you know, bunched together in such a small spot in the sky.
Do you need a telescope to see them or can you just go out and take a look?
No.
Jupiter - Jupiter and Mercury, Jupiter especially, should be readily evident as a fairly bright star on the - just above the East-Southeast horizon.
Once you pick that out, you should have no problem in also discerning or picking out Mercury, which will be close by.
Mercury won't be quite as bright.
But Mars, I wouldn't suggest trying to use a telescope, only because a telescope, you know, it kind of restricts your view, so to speak.
Binoculars, however, which I always suggest to people, are probably the best instrument that you can use.
You can readily, once you get Jupiter in view, just train your binoculars on Jupiter and immediately you'll pick out Mercury, and Mars should be also evident as well.
Let me go - let me continue in our chronological order of things.
Isn't there a night launch of the space shuttle scheduled one of these days when the weather cooperates?
Right.
Well, the shuttle, of course, was supposed to - Shuttle Discovery was supposed to go off last night.
And of course, they had low clouds at Cape Canaveral and that precluded getting the vehicle off.
They are tentatively said to try again tomorrow evening.
I think something like 8:50 p.m. Eastern time.
And folks who are located along the Eastern seaboard, since this is a night launch, the shuttle track is going to be pretty much parallel to the East Coast.
